name: Asian Pork Chop with Ginger Soy Sauce
description: This simple recipe for tender, pan-fried Asian Pork Chop marinated in a ginger soy glaze makes a delicious weeknight dinner with steamed rice.
recipeIngredient: ½–1 Tbsp sugar ((adjust according to your liking))
½ tsp potato starch or cornstarch

itemListElement.text: Prick 4 boneless pork loin chops (½-inch thick) with a fork so the meat will absorb the marinade. In a resealable plastic bag, add the pork chops and all the ingredients for the marinade: 3 Tbsp soy sauce, 2 Tbsp sake, 2 tsp toasted sesame oil, ½–1 Tbsp sugar, 1 clove garlic (minced), 1 tsp ginger (julienned), ½ tsp potato starch or cornstarch, and 1 shallot (minced). Squeeze out the air before sealing the bag. Keep in the refrigerator for 30 minutes; I don‘t recommend longer than that as it gets too salty.
itemListElement.name: Prick 4 boneless pork loin chops (½-inch thick) with a fork so the meat will absorb the marinade. In a resealable plastic bag, add the pork chops and all the ingredients for the marinade: 3 Tbsp soy sauce, 2 Tbsp sake, 2 tsp toasted sesame oil, ½–1 Tbsp sugar, 1 clove garlic (minced), 1 tsp ginger (julienned), ½ tsp potato starch or cornstarch, and 1 shallot (minced). Squeeze out the air before sealing the bag. Keep in the refrigerator for 30 minutes; I don‘t recommend longer than that as it gets too salty.

itemListElement.text: You can grill the pork chops on the BBQ or you can pan-fry. For pan-frying, heat 1 Tbsp neutral oil in a large pan on medium-high heat. When it’s hot, add the pork chops to the pan, removing the marinade from the pork chop as the moisture will end up “steaming“ the meat. Keep the marinade in the plastic bag as we‘ll use it later. Cook the pork chops until the bottom side is nicely brown.
itemListElement.name: You can grill the pork chops on the BBQ or you can pan-fry. For pan-frying, heat 1 Tbsp neutral oil in a large pan on medium-high heat. When it’s hot, add the pork chops to the pan, removing the marinade from the pork chop as the moisture will end up “steaming“ the meat. Keep the marinade in the plastic bag as we‘ll use it later. Cook the pork chops until the bottom side is nicely brown.

itemListElement.text: Once the meat is brown, flip it and lower the heat to medium low. Cover the pan with a lid and cook for 3 minutes. You want to make sure the pork is cooked through, but do not overcook because it will get very tough.
itemListElement.name: Once the meat is brown, flip it and lower the heat to medium low. Cover the pan with a lid and cook for 3 minutes. You want to make sure the pork is cooked through, but do not overcook because it will get very tough.

itemListElement.text: Add the marinade into the pan and increase the heat to medium. Bring it to simmer and scoop the sauce with a spoon over the meat. Transfer the meat to serving plates. Continue to reduce the sauce until thickened.
itemListElement.name: Add the marinade into the pan and increase the heat to medium. Bring it to simmer and scoop the sauce with a spoon over the meat. Transfer the meat to serving plates. Continue to reduce the sauce until thickened.

itemListElement.text: Serve the pork chop with steamed rice and sautéed vegetables (I sautéed spinach with butter and seasoned with salt and pepper). Enjoy!
itemListElement.name: Serve the pork chop with steamed rice and sautéed vegetables (I sautéed spinach with butter and seasoned with salt and pepper). Enjoy!

itemListElement.text: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

review.reviewBody: 10/10 would make again.  Used the lesser amount of sugar and would not use more.  Cooked perfectly.

Namiko-san, 
Hello! If I may ask your advice, could mochiko flour or corn starch be used instead of potato starch? I don’t have any on hand at the moment and I’m eager to try this recipe. I’m so happy I came across your site; I really enjoy Japanese cooking. I’ve tried, and love, your mentsuyu recipe and seriously look forward to eating more authentic Japanese cooking. Thank you so much for sharing your recipes. お疲れ様でした！

I just tried it. Like, JUST finished cooking and eating, and while I usually pick at my food after the first few bites, I devoured everything on my plate. My husband turned up his nose a bit when I told him I was cooking his beloved chops Asian style, but he loved it, too!! It was excellent and healthier than the pork chops I usually cook. My only issue was that there wasn't NEAR enough sauce for the rice. However, the flavor was deep enough to stretch. I'll just double the marinade portion of the recipe next time! Thank you! Will make again.

Just finished having this for dinner. It was absolutely delicious! Steamed some rice, and veggies. My fiance gobbled it right up and left the table full! The marinade was also really well balanced. Not too sweet, not too salty. If I had room for more, I'd definitely go back for seconds!
